column69: Reset PC to Default Address (Internal instruction, no machine code for this)
CPU Status Register - Output to bus
Register B - Output to bus (L8 / H8[AL != 0x0])
Register X (ALU Output) - Output to bus (L8)
Memory Address Register - Input from bus (16)
PC - Input from bus (L8 [MO High] / I{3,2,1})
PC - Increment (All instructions have final microstep PS=1)
ALU Operation. Decoded in the ALU to select from 15 operations.
Register B - Output to H8 (Doesn't control BO)

Reset CPU Status register (pin also labeled DO), active low, so must be high to inhibit reset. HOWEVER, to facilitate the hack I implemented that solders this control line directly to the normal ~{CI} net, we actually have to set this HIGH in order to enable the status register to be written to. So this specific ISA is setup so that the only times you can write to the status register is during ALU operations.
Branch circuit sets PI according to result
Branch, and JMP instructions do NOT have final microcode instruction to increment PS
Instruction bit15 enables four extra bits from the instruction to be output to the data bus

column2: Load B from address in A
Load A from address in B
column69: Instructions with 8bit immediate values always use 0110 as their top 4 bits.

column2: Copy B to address in A
Copy A to address in B
